t: Job 6
Job
Then*p Job replied:
“If*pn only my anguish could be weighed and*ld all my misery be placed on the scales!
It*ln would surely outweigh the sand of the seas— no*ld wonder my words have been impetuous.
The*ln arrows of the Almighty are in me, my*ld spirit drinks in their poison; God’s*ld terrors are marshaled against me.
Does*ln a wild donkey bray when it has grass, or*ld an ox bellow when it has fodder?
Is*ln tasteless food eaten without salt, or*ld is there flavor in the sap of the mallow?
I*ln refuse to touch it; such*ld food makes me ill.
“Oh,*pn that I might have my request, that*ld God would grant what I hope for,
that*ln God would be willing to crush me, to*ld let loose his hand and cut off my life!
Then*ln I would still have this consolation— my*ld joy in unrelenting pain— that*ld I had not denied the words of the Holy One.
“What*pn strength do I have, that I should still hope? What*ld prospects, that I should be patient?
Do*ln I have the strength of stone? Is*ld my flesh bronze?
Do*ln I have any power to help myself, now*ld that success has been driven from me?
“Anyone*pn who withholds kindness from a friend forsakes*ld the fear of the Almighty.
But*ln my brothers are as undependable as intermittent streams, as*ld the streams that overflow
when*ln darkened by thawing ice and*ld swollen with melting snow,
but*ln that stop flowing in the dry season, and*ld in the heat vanish from their channels.
Caravans*ln turn aside from their routes; they*ld go off into the wasteland and perish.
The*ln caravans of Tema look for water, the*ld traveling merchants of Sheba look in hope.
They*ln are distressed, because they had been confident; they*ld arrive there, only to be disappointed.
Now*ln you too have proved to be of no help; you*ld see something dreadful and are afraid.
Have*ln I ever said, ‘Give something on my behalf, pay*ld a ransom for me from your wealth,
deliver*ln me from the hand of the enemy, rescue*ld me from the clutches of the ruthless’?
“Teach*pn me, and I will be quiet; show*ld me where I have been wrong.
How*ln painful are honest words! But*ld what do your arguments prove?
Do*ln you mean to correct what I say, and*ld treat my desperate words as wind?
You*ln would even cast lots for the fatherless and*ld barter away your friend.
“But*pn now be so kind as to look at me. Would*ld I lie to your face?
Relent,*ln do not be unjust; reconsider,*ld for my integrity is at stake.
Is*ln there any wickedness on my lips? Can*ld my mouth not discern malice?
